David Jackman wrote:
> Actually, if you were really following TDD then you wouldn't have
> the private method unless it was already covered by tests.  At
> least that's the methodology I use (no change happens to my code
> until there's a failing test forcing the change, except for
> refactoring).  So the code coverage tool shouldn't be (as)
> necessary.  I've found I only use them for those project where
> (someone else :) wrote the code without writing tests first.
> In that case, it helps to know the coverage, but also can give
> me a false sense of security.
>  

David,

This is the way I practice TDD as well -- test first. I've been
learning that not everyone is as disciplined as we are. Code coverage
tools /can/ be a two-edged sword. I use it as an audit check for how
well I'm adhering to TDD. Sometimes I can still slip and this helps me
identify my own backsliding ways early so I can correct the problem by
adding the right tests. But you are correct, just because the code is
being executed by a test does not mean that it is adequately tested.

My recommendation was that a coverage tool be used to provide
confidence that private methods are being executed by existing tests
through the public API. The impluse that leads to making the private
method public for testing might diminish if one could be shown that
there was no need. Do you think it would be preferable in that context
to measure code coverage before making methods public?

Regards,
Jim
